lessons.title: Needs, Wants, and Goals
lessons.content: You make dozens of money choices every week. Separating needs (must-haves) from wants (nice-to-haves) helps you control spending and reach your goals. A SMART goal is Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. Example: “Save $150 for prom shoes by May 1 by setting aside $15 per week.” When a want competes with a goal, compare the short-term fun with the long-term payoff. Opportunity cost is what you give up when you choose one option over another—skipping three takeout meals might fund a month of phone service or boost your emergency fund.

activities.prompt: Drag each item to Need or Want for Jordan this month.
Write a SMART saving goal for the next 30 days.

activities.explain: Make it specific, measurable, realistic, relevant, and dated.

mastery_check.prompt: Which statement is a SMART goal?
mastery_check.explain: It’s specific, measurable, time-bound, and has a clear method.

mastery_check.prompt: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative you give up.
mastery_check.explain: Choosing one thing means not choosing another—time and money are limited.

lessons.title: Decision Grids and Trade-offs
lessons.content: A decision grid helps you compare options using criteria you care about. List choices across the top (e.g., “Buy used bike,” “Bus pass,” “Rideshare”) and criteria down the side (cost, convenience, time, safety). Score each 1–5 and total the columns. Grids don’t decide for you—they reveal trade-offs so you can choose with eyes open. Reread your goals and pick the option that best supports them, not just what feels good today.

lessons.content: Spending triggers are people, places, or moods that lead to impulse buys. Use if–then plans to stay on track: “If friends suggest food after practice, then I’ll spend max $8 or suggest eating at home.” Replace costly habits with low-cost alternatives and keep goals visible (phone lock-screen).
